advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> BROCHURE - COVER</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.retrorene.nl/" target="_blank">Retro Rene's Gaming Corner</a> for this picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> 1979 RANGE ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert shows: <br><br> - the <b>WH89</b> computer ($2295)<br> - the <b>WH11A</b> 16-bit computer, DEC PDP 11/03 compatible ($1895)<br> - the <b>WH19</b> video terminal ($995)<br> - the <b>WH26</b> dual floppy disc system ($2595)<br> - the <b>WH14</b> serial printer ($895)<br><br> To note: in 1979, the company name was <b>Heath Schlumberger data systems.</b> </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (1980)</strong></font><br><blockquote>This french advert dated may 1980, shows the first model sold in France. It was called Victor Lambda and the company name was Lambda Systemes. This model was nothing more than an Interact computer, sold with an english documentation and a NTSC television !</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> 1946...</strong></font><br><blockquote>This is an extract of the promotional guide. It says: <br><br> <font color="#666666">1946... Today the TO 7<br> 1946: 30 tons, 160 m²<br> Today: 3.5 Kg, 0.01 m²</font> </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (MAY 1984)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT #2</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.cobit.kit.net" target="_blank">COB-Clube Old Bits</a> for this picture.</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (MAY 1980)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> AUSTRALIAN TANDY CATALOG (1992)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> 8-PAGE US ADVERT #5</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.K. AD. (DEC. 1985)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Special Christmas offer with 12 games.<br><br> Monochrome version: <b>£199</b><br> Colour version: <b>£299</b><br></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROMOTIONAL PICTURE</strong></font><br><blockquote>Happy family playing "La quête des anneaux" (Quest for the rings)</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> US AD. 1983 #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>Hard disk version<br><br> "<font color="#666666">No matter how you look at it, KAYPRO is the best value you will see anawhere...</font>"</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. AD #2 (1983) </strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br><font color="#666666"> The columbia MPC is shipped with fully suported software that will save you $3,000. Included is the entire self-teaching Perfect Software family: Perfect Writer, a word processor; Perfect Speller, a 50,000 word dictionnary; Perfect Filer, a data base manager; and Perfect Calc, a financial calculation system.<br><br> In addition, you get MS-DOS, CP/M-86, Macro/86 assembler, BASICA, Asynchronous communication support, Diagnostics and the Columbia Tutor program...</font></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> LEAFLET (1982) - PAGE 3</strong></font><br><blockquote>Notice that the box arts are completely different from the final ones (see software section)</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> GERMAN BROCHURE #2</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Volken</b></p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> VICTOR AD #2 (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>In this advert, the Victor 9000 features was compared with those of four competitor computers: IBM PC, Xerox 820, Apple III and TRS-80 Model II. <br><br> Victor features was definitely higher than all of the desktop computers of the time, including the IBM PC. </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (JULY 1985)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Page 1</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FIRST AD</strong></font><br><blockquote>February 1983<br><br> Advert said:<br><br><font color="#666666"> For years, people have been trying to build a better Apple II.<br> It finally happened.<br> Meet the Apple IIe, an impressive new version of a most impressive machine.<br> The 'e' means enhanced. Which means a bundle of new features...</font></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.K. AD. 1984</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br><font color="#666666"> ... With the knowledge that Mitsubishi is the largest manufacturer of Mainframe computers in Japan, those in the know will immediately recognise the true potential of the Mitsubishi F-series...</font></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> PREVIOUS SYSTEM</strong></font><br><blockquote>Before manufacturing the MPC, Columbia tried to sell a massive multi-user, Z80 based system.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1979)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT (1984)</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to Tony Mattson for this picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE AD</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> BRAZILIAN ADVERT (1985)</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.mci.org.br" target="_blank">Museu da Computação e Informática - MCI</a> for this picture.</p></blockquote>

computer.cpu: 65C12 - CMOS version of the 6502 with minor technical changes
computer.description:
The Olivetti PC 128S was exactly the same machine as the Acorn BBC Master compact. It was sold only in Italy.
Olivetti merely transformed the case design with nice blue and grey patterns and translated all the programs of the original Acorn Welcome disk, as well as the manual into Italian language.
Although it was one of the most advanced 8-bit computer, the PC 128S, like its predecessor, the PC 128, didn't meet a large success, mainly because it came to late on the market, just at the time when the new Atari and Commodore 16-bit machines were launched in Europe.
computer.graphics: 640 x 256 (2 colors) / 320 x 256 (4 colors) / 160 x 256 (16 colors)
computer.keyboard: Full-stroke 93-key with 10 function keys and numeric keypad
computer.name: Prodest PC 128S
computer.ports: RGB & Composite video out, RS232 (optional), Econet port (optional), Parallel printer, Disk-drive, Joystick/mouse, expansion edge connector
computer.power: Switching PSU in the expansion box
computer.rom: 64 KB - OS: 32 KB, BASIC: 16 KB, ADFS: 16 KB

shot.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> RUNNING SYSTEM</strong></font><br><blockquote>Welcome logo of the utility and programs diskette.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> LEFT & RIGHT SIDES</strong></font><br><blockquote>On the right side, the bus expansion connector.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> REAR SIDES</strong></font><br><blockquote>Main unit, from left to right:<br> • Expansion connector (right side)<br> • RGB DIN socket<br> • Composite video jack<br> • locations for optional RS232 and Econet connectors<br> • Joystick/mouse DB9 connector<br> • Parallel printer connector<br> • External floppy-disk drive DB25 connector<br> • DC 5V input conector. Power is supplied by the expansion unit<br><br> Expansion unit<br> • Male and female power plugs, fuses and power switch.<br> • 5V power lead and disk interface flat cable, both are nornally connected to the main unit.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> MAINBOARD</strong></font><br><blockquote><b><font color="blue">(1)</font></b> Empty sockets for the optional RS232 interface<br> <b><font color="blue">(2)</font></b> Connectors for the optional Econet card<br> <b><font color="blue">(3)</font></b> SAA-5050 Teletext character generator (Mode 7)<br> <b><font color="blue">(4)</font></b> Custom chip. Address decoder for various peripherals<br> <b><font color="blue">(5)</font></b> 65SC12 microprocessor<br> <b><font color="blue">(6)</font></b> Custom chip dedicated to ROM and RAM bank switching<br> <b><font color="blue">(7)</font></b> 64 KB system ROM. Up to 4 additional ROMs can be added<br> <b><font color="blue">(8)</font></b> 128 KB RAM chips (4x4464)<br> <b><font color="blue">(9)</font></b> Custom chip in charge of the video RAM management<br> <b><font color="blue">(10)</font></b> 6845 video chipset (First IBM PC monochrome and colour cards used the same chipset)<br> <b><font color="blue">(11)</font></b> Custom chip used to manage the system's data bus<br> <b><font color="blue">(12)</font></b> 6522 VIA chips (Versatile Interface Adapter) in charge of various I/O<br> <b><font color="blue">(13)</font></b> Western Digital WD1772 floppy-disk controller</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> INSIDE THE EXPANSION MODULE</strong></font><br><blockquote>Sony double-sided, single density floppy-disk drive and switching PSU, also used for the main unit. Provision is made for a second 3.5" drive.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> MANUALS</strong></font><br><blockquote>User manual, command summary cards for the 'Sheet' word processor, spreadsheet and database programs, Welcome diskette and even the warranty card :-)</blockquote>

computer.size: Keyboard unit: 42.5 (W) x 21.7 (D) x 7.7 (H) cmExpansion unit: 35.1 (W) x 33.3 (D) x 9.5 (H) cm
computer.text: 80 x 32/25 (2 colors) / 40 x 32/25 (2 or 4 colors) / 20 x 32 (16 colors) / 40 x 25 (Teletext display)
